revision.comment: it debuted at #21 on 7 july 2013 per UK R&B, the following week it went to 15
revision.text:
{{Infobox song | name = Tunnel Vision | cover = Justin Timberlake_-_Tunnel Vision.png | border = yes | alt = A black-and-white close-up of a man's face within a naked woman's silhouette. With golden letters within the covers the words 'JT' and 'Tunnel Vision' are written. | type = single | artist = [[Justin Timberlake]] | album = [[The 20/20 Experience]] | released = {{Start date|2013|06|14}} | format = [[music download|Digital download]] | recorded = May–July 2012 | studio = Larrabee, North Hollywood, California | genre = [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]<!-- Sourced in the composition section --> | length = {{Duration|m=4|s=43}} | label = [[RCA Records|RCA]] | writer = *Justin Timberlake *[[Timbaland|Timothy Mosley]] *[[J-Roc (record producer)|Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]] *[[James Fauntleroy]] | producer = *[[Timbaland]] *Justin Timberlake *Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon | prev_title = [[Mirrors (Justin Timberlake song)|Mirrors]] | prev_year = 2013 | next_title = [[Holy Grail (Jay-Z song)|Holy Grail]] | next_year = 2013 }} "'''Tunnel Vision'''" is a song recorded by American singer [[Justin Timberlake]] for his third [[studio album]], ''[[The 20/20 Experience]]'' (2013). It was written and produced by Timberlake, [[Timbaland|Timothy "Timbaland" Mosley]] and [[J-Roc (record producer)|Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]], with additional writing by [[James Fauntleroy]]. "Tunnel Vision" was digitally released on June 14, 2013 by [[RCA Records]] as the third single from the album. It is a mid-tempo [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] song with [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] influence and instrumentation featuring Timbaland's signature [[ad-libs]], record-[[scratching]], heavy [[drum]]s, melodic [[Bass (music)|bass]], [[orchestration]] and [[synthesizer]]. Its lyrics proclaim Timberlake's [[tunnel vision]] for his love interest, with several [[Voyeurism|voyeuristic]] references.
"Tunnel Vision" received generally positive reviews from [[Music journalism|music critics]], most of whom praised Timbaland's production, and it was cited as ''The 20/20 Experience''{{'}}s highlight. After the album's release, the song charted in South Korea and the United States because of high digital sales. It debuted on the [[Gaon Chart|singles chart]] in South Korea at number 27, selling 6,670 digital copies in its first week. "Tunnel Vision" peaked at number 40 on the US [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|''Billboard'' Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] chart, and number eight on the UK [[UK R&B Chart|R&B Singles Chart]].
The [[music video]] for "Tunnel Vision" was directed by [[Jonathan Craven]], Simon McLoughlin and Jeff Nicholas, and premiered on July 3 on Timberlake's [[Vevo]] channel. In the seven-minute video, Timberlake and Timbaland watch nude women and dance. Critics labeled the video [[Not suitable for work|NSFW]] and compared it to the video for [[Robin Thicke]]'s 2013 single, "[[Blurred Lines]]". Originally banned on [[YouTube]], it was later posted with the condition that viewers disclose their age. The song was part of the [[set list]] for Timberlake's 2013 [[Legends of the Summer]] concert tour with rapper [[Jay-Z]] and his fifth solo tour, the 2013–15 [[The 20/20 Experience World Tour|20/20 Experience World Tour]].
== Production and release == [[File:Timbaland1292010.png|upright|left|thumbnail|alt=An African-American man is wearing headphones while performing|[[Timbaland]] co-wrote and co-produced "Tunnel Vision".]] "Tunnel Vision" was written by Justin Timberlake, Timothy "Timbaland" Mosley, [[J-Roc (record producer)|Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon]] and [[James Fauntleroy]], and produced by Timbaland, Timberlake and Harmon. Timberlake arranged and produced his vocals, which were recorded at Larabee Studios in North Hollywood, California. Other instrumentalists were Harmon on keyboards and Elliot Ives on guitar. The song was engineered by Chris Godbey (assisted by Alejandro Baima) and [[audio mixing (recorded music)|mixed]] by Jimmy Douglass, Godbey and Timberlake at Larabee Studios.<ref name="Album Credits"/>
On June 10, 2013 Timberlake introduced the artwork for the "Tunnel Vision" single, a [[black-and-white]] close-up of the singer's face in the silhouette of a nude woman.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a488786/justin-timberlake-unveils-new-single-tunnel-vision-artwork-picture.html|title=Justin Timberlake unveils new single 'Tunnel Vision' artwork – picture|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|last=Corner|first=Lewis|date=June 10, 2013|accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rap-up.com/2013/06/10/single-cover-justin-timberlake-tunnel-vision|title=Single Cover: Justin Timberlake – 'Tunnel Vision'|work=[[Rap-Up]]|accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> Kia Macarechi of [[The Huffington Post]] found the artwork unpleasant and unusual;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/12/justin-timberlake-tunnel-vision-single-art_n_3427495.html|title=Justin Timberlake's 'Tunnel Vision' Single Art Is Very Awkward (Photo)|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|last=Macarechi|first=Kia|date=June 12, 2013|accessdate=June 27, 2013}}</ref> according to Justin Myers of the [[Official Charts Company]], Timberlake "seems to be playing up to his naughty nickname of Trousersnake with the cover".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://officialcharts.com/chart-news/oo-er-saucy-artwork-for-justin-timberlakes-tunnel-vision-revealed-2282/|title=Oo-er! Saucy artwork for Justin Timberlake's Tunnel Vision revealed|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|last=Myers|first=Justin|date=June 14, 2013|accessdate=June 27, 2013}}</ref> Zach Dionne of ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''{{'}}s ''[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]'' website called the cover "awful boobnose single art", committing to "the smoky naked woman vibe".<ref name="vulture review">{{cite web|url=https://vulture.com/2013/07/justin-timberlake-tunnel-vision-video.html|title=Justin Timberlake's NSFW 'Tunnel Vision' Video Got Pulled, Came Back|work=[[Vulture (blog)|Vulture]]. [[New York (magazine)|New York]]|last=Dionne|first=Zach|date=July 7, 2013|accessdate=July 13, 2013}}</ref> "Tunnel Vision" and its radio edit were digitally released in France and Italy on June 14 on [[Amazon.com|Amazon]].<ref name="france dd"/><ref name="italy dd"/> That day, the single was also released in Australia,<ref name="australia dd"/> Belgium,<ref name="belgium dd"/> Luxembourg,<ref name="Luxembourg dd"/> The Netherlands,<ref name="NL dd"/> New Zealand<ref name="NZ dd"/> and Sweden on [[7 Digital]] and the [[iTunes Store]].<ref name="sweden dd"/> It was released on June 17 in Norway,<ref name="norway dd"/> the following day in Spain and on June 21 in Switzerland.<ref name="spain dd"/><ref name="switzerland"/> {{Clear}}
== Composition and lyrics == {{listen|filename=Tunnel Vision.ogg|title="Tunnel Vision" |description=A 30-second sample of "Tunnel Vision", a mid-tempo [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] song with [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] influences that features "sinister" synthesizer and [[Middle Eastern]] tones |pos=right |format=[[Ogg]]}}
"Tunnel Vision" is a mid-tempo<ref name=Hollywood>{{cite web|last=Bentley |first=Jean |url=http://hollywood.com/news/celebrities/55003811/justin-timberlake-the-20-20-experience-streaming-review |title=Justin Timberlake's 'The 20/20 Experience' is Streaming Online Right Now! An Early Review |publisher=Hollywood.com |date=March 11, 2013 |accessdate=March 18, 2013}}</ref> [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] song with an [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] influence.<ref name="drownedinsound">{{cite web|url=http://drownedinsound.com/releases/17535/reviews/4146182|title=Justin Timberlake – The 20/20 Experience|publisher=[[Drowned in Sound]]|last=Rolle|first=Kat|date=March 18, 2013|accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> ''Billboard'''s Jason Lipshutz noted that it has an [[Instrumentation (music)|instrumentation]] that features "fizzing [[Beat (music)|beats]] abetted by the producer's [Timbaland] signature [[ad-libs]] and vocal record-scratches",<ref name=Billboard>{{cite web|url=https://billboard.com/articles/review/1551360/justin-timberlake-the-2020-experience-track-by-track-review |title=Justin Timberlake, 'The 20/20 Experience': Track-by-Track Review |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=March 12, 2013 |accessdate=March 18, 2013}}</ref> while according to Sobhi Youssef of [[Sputnikmusic]] the song is built on "still-existing chops with a drum heavy, syncopated backbone amidst frenetically shifting bass melodies, sweeping [[orchestrations]], and vacuous synths that all coalesce into a fuzzed out boom-bap."<ref name="sputnik">{{cite web|url=http://sputnikmusic.com/review/55739/Justin-Timberlake-The-20-20-Experience/|title=Justin Timberlake – The 20/20 Experience|publisher=[[Sputnikmusic]]|last=Youssef|first=Sobhi|date=March 15, 2013|accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> Ryan Dombal of [[Pitchfork Media]] called the synthesizer "sinister"<ref name="Pitchfork">{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17736-justin-timberlake-the-2020-experience/|title=Justin Timberlake – The 20/20 Experience|publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]]|last=Dombal|first=Ryan|date=March 19, 2013|accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> and, according to [[Slant Magazine]]'s Eric Henderson, it has [[Middle Eastern]] tones.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://slantmagazine.com/music/review/justin-timberlake-the-20-20-experience/3000|title=Justin Timberlake: The 20/20 Experience|publisher=[[Slant Magazine]]|last=Henderson|first=Eric|date=March 16, 2013|accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> Joey Guerra of the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' called the beats and vocal loops on "Tunnel Vision" reminiscent of Timbaland's past work with the late American singer [[Aaliyah]].<ref name=Chron>{{cite news|url=https://chron.com/life/article/Not-a-drop-of-hindsight-on-forward-looking-20-20-4358347.php |title=Not a drop of hindsight on forward-looking '20/20' – Houston Chronicle |work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=March 15, 2013 |accessdate=March 18, 2013}}</ref> According to Sarah Dean of ''The Huffington Post'', its beat resembles that on [[50 Cent]]'s 2007 single "[[Ayo Technology]]" (also featuring Timberlake).<ref name=Huffington>{{cite web|url=http://huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/03/01/justin-timberlake-the-20-20-experience_n_2788429.html |title=Justin Timberlake 'The 20/20 Experience' Review: It's Good to Hear from an Old Friend |publisher=The Huffington Post|last=Dean|first=Sarah |date=March 15, 2013 |accessdate=March 19, 2013}}</ref>
"Tunnel Vision" features "thrilling" evolutions in production and arrangement complementing Timberlake's vocals,<ref name=Billboard/> and the song's unusual, abrupt changes unite it throughout.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://musicomh.com/reviews/albums/justin-timberlake-the-2020-experience|title=Justin Timberlake – The 20/20 Experience|publisher=[[MusicOMH]]|last=Meller|first=David|date=March 15, 2013|accessdate=March 17, 2013}}</ref> It borrows the "dark alley" rhythm of ''The 20/20 Experience''{{'}}s third track, "[[Don't Hold the Wall]]"; Timberlake sings in his lower register, with an "exciting" upward [[arpeggio]].<ref name="CONSEQUENCEOFSOUND">{{cite web|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2013/03/album-review-justin-timberlake-the-2020-experience/|title=Album Review: Justin Timberlake – The 20/20 Experience|publisher=[[Consequence of Sound]]|first=Sarah H|last=Grant|date=March 19, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref> Timbaland uses the singer's voice as a "flexible instrument to enhance his tech savvy soundscape",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hiphopdx.com/index/album-reviews/id.2051/title.justin-timberlake-the-20-20-experience|title=Justin Timberlake – The 20/20 Experience|publisher=HipHopDx|last=Inadoli|first=Kathy|date=March 18, 2013|accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref> constructing "layers of production elements into towers of sonic force".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://westernherald.com/arts-and-entertainment/album-review-justin-timberlakes-latest-is-pop-excess-at-its-finest/|title=Album Review: Justin Timberlake’s latest is pop excess at its finest|work=[[Western Herald]]|last=Manning|first=Craig|date=March 20, 2013|access-date=March 28, 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140527182840/http://westernherald.com/arts-and-entertainment/album-review-justin-timberlakes-latest-is-pop-excess-at-its-finest/|archive-date=May 27, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> Lauren Martin of ''[[Fact (UK magazine)|Fact]]'' called the song the start of Timbaland's "[[Bollywood]] influenced '[[Indian Flute]]' era" and a tease; Timberlake's voice is redistributed, with wider [[Range (music)|range]] and suspense.<ref name="FACTMAG">{{cite web|url=http://factmag.com/2013/03/18/justin-timberlake-the-2020-experience-fact-review/|title=Justin Timberlake – The 20/20 Experience|work=[[Fact (UK magazine)|Fact]]|last=Martin|first=Lauren|date=March 18, 2013|accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref>
The song's lyrics describe Timberlake's [[tunnel vision]] of his love interest, with several [[Voyeurism|voyeuristic]] references.<ref name="Pitchfork"/><ref name="MTV">{{cite web|url=http://mtv.com/news/articles/1703486/justin-timberlake-20-20-experience.jhtml|title=Justin Timberlake's The 20/20 Experience: The Bachelor, The Bride, And The In-Between|publisher=[[MTV News]]|last=Montgomery|first=James|date=March 12, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref> The singer professes his love: "I look around and everything I see is beautiful, because all I see is you."<ref name=Huffington/> According to ''The Huffington Post'''s Dean, Timberlake is in happier state of mind than on his 2002 song "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]" or his 2007 single "[[What Goes Around... Comes Around]]".<ref name=Huffington/> However, his lyrics have an obsessive quality: "A million people in a crowded room, but my camera lens is only set to zoom and it all becomes so clear."<ref name="Buzzworhty">{{cite web|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2013/03/14/justin-timberlake-2020-experience-review-gifs/|title=Justin Timberlake 'The 20/20 Experience': Track-By-Track Review... In GIFs!|publisher=MTV Buzzworthy|last=Stern|first=Brad|date=March 14, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref> Mellisa Maerz of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' wrote that on "Tunnel Vision", Timberlake is lyrically "playing the rom-com director": "Just like a movie shoot, I’m zoomin’ in on you as we ride off into the sun."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2013/03/11/justin-timberlake-the-20-20-experience-review/|title=Justin Timberlake streams 'The 20/20 Experience' on iTunes. Worth the seven-year wait? – The EW Review|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|last=Maerz|first=Melissa|date=March 11, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref> According to Mikael Wood of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', Timberlake uses references to "cameras and reflective surfaces" to reflect on the "changing nature of celebrity".<ref>{{cite web|title=Album review: Justin Timberlake's 'The 20/20 Experience'|url=https://latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-album-review-justin-timberlake-the-20-20-experience-20130314,0,1032937.story|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last=Wood|first=Mikael|date=March 14, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref>
== Critical reception == [[Consequence of Sound]]'s Sarah H. Grant wrote that "Tunnel Vision" and "Don't Hold the Wall" were the album's highlights, similar to Timberlake's best work with [['NSYNC]].<ref name="CONSEQUENCEOFSOUND"/> Clyde Erwin Barretto of ''Prefix Magazine'' praised its production, which he felt excited listeners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prefixmag.com/reviews/justin-timberlake/the-2020-experience/73185/|title=Album Review: Justin Timberlake – The 20/20 Experience|publisher=Prefix Magazine|last=Barretto|first=Clyde Erwin|date=March 20, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref> ''The Huffington Post''{{'}}s Sarah Dean called "Tunnel Vision" her favorite track on the album.<ref name=Huffington/> Jordan Sargent of ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' wrote that with the song, Timbaland proved that he could still produce otherworldly beats.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://spin.com/reviews/justin-timberlake-the-20-20-experience-rca|title=Justin Timberlake, 'The 20/20 Experience' (RCA)|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|last=Sargent|first=Jordan|date=March 18, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref> In ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[Kitty Empire]] wrote that Timbaland rejuvenated his production talents and "[[Kanye West|Kanye]]-calibre ambition".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://guardian.co.uk/culture/2013/mar/17/justin-timberlake-20-experience-review|title=Justin Timberlake: The 20/20 Experience – review|work=[[The Guardian]]|last=Empire|first=Kitty|date=March 17, 2013|accessdate=March 29, 2013}}</ref>
In a less-enthusiastic review, Brad Stern of MTV Buzzworthy dismissed "Tunnel Vision" as "the album's most tediously grating moment".<ref name="Buzzworhty"/> Allan Raible of ABC News praised the track's beat, but thought it would fit better on a song with fewer "tired 'loverman' clichés."<ref name="ABC NEWS">{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2013/03/review-justin-timberlakes-the-2020-experience/|title=Review: Justin Timberlake's 'The 20/20 Experience'|publisher=[[ABC News]]|last=Rabile|first=Allan|date=March 23, 2013|accessdate=March 27, 2013}}</ref> ''Fact'' magazine's Lauren Martin described "Tunnel Vision" and "Don't Hold the Wall" as "two rousing, if mildly deja vu inducing, efforts."<ref name="FACTMAG"/> Jed Gottlieb of the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' said that the song's "electro bump" would have been innovative if it had been released a year earlier.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gottlieb |first=Jed |url=http://bostonherald.com/entertainment/music/album_reviews/2013/03/justin_timberlake_robs_from_the_past_for_his_new_release |title=Justin Timberlake robs from the past for his new release |work=[[Boston Herald]]|date=March 17, 2013 |accessdate=March 18, 2013}}</ref>
== Chart performance == "Tunnel Vision" sold well digitally after the release of ''The 20/20 Experience'', charting in several countries. The week of March 17, 2013, it debuted on the South Korean [[Gaon Chart|Gaon International Chart]] at number 27 with 6,670 digital copies sold.<ref name="South Korea Debut"/> Although it did not reach the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]] in the United States, "Tunnel Vision" peaked at number 11 on the [[Bubbling Under Hot 100]] singles chart<ref name="bubbling">{{cite web | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=Justin Timberlake|chart=Bubbling Under Hot 100}} | title=Justin Timberlake chart history – Bubbling Under Hot 100 | work=Billboard | accessdate=April 13, 2013}}</ref> and peaked at number 40 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|''Billboard '' Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] chart.<ref name="r&biphop"/> After its release as a single, the song debuted and peaked at number 75 on the [[Irish Singles Chart]].<ref name="irish"/> The week of July 20, "Tunnel Vision" debuted at number 64 on the [[UK Singles Chart]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://officialcharts.com/singles-chart/ |title=Official UK Singles Top 100 – 20th July 2013 |publisher=Official Charts Company |access-date=August 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312030200/http://www.officialcharts.com/singles-chart/ |url-status=live |archive-date=March 12, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Its chart position fluctuated for three weeks, peaking at number 61 on August 10.<ref name="uk peak"/> The song was most successful on the UK [[UK R&B Chart|R&B Singles Chart]], where it debuted at number 21<ref>{{cite web |title=Official R&B Singles Chart Top 40 |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/r-and-b-singles-chart/20130707/114/ |publisher=Official Charts Company |accessdate=3 May 2020 |date=7 July 2013}}</ref> and peaked at number eight by the week of August 10.<ref name="R&b chart"/>
== Music video ==
=== Conception and fashion === [[File:Tunnel Vision screenshot.png|thumbnail|left|alt=Silhouettes of three women on which a man's face is projected|Screenshot from the music video, in which Timberlake's face is projected on the women's nude bodies]] "Tunnel Vision"'s [[music video]] premiered on July 3, 2013 on Timberlake's [[Vevo]] [[YouTube]] channel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=07FYdnEawAQ|title=Justin Timberlake – Tunnel Vision (Explicit)|publisher=[[Vevo]]. [[YouTube]]|accessdate=July 4, 2013}}</ref> The singer [[Twitter|tweeted]], "Check out the new video for Tunnel Vision and be ready...it's explicit. -teamJT".<ref name="video ban"/> The video was directed by [[Jonathan Craven]], Simon McLoughlin and Jeff Nicholas, with a cameo appearance by Timbaland.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/51410-watch-justin-timberlakes-tunnel-vision-video-features-lots-of-female-nudity-timbaland/|title=Watch: Justin Timberlake's "Tunnel Vision" Video Features Lots of Female Nudity, Timbaland|publisher=Pitchfork Media|last=Minsker|first=Evan|date=July 3, 2013|accessdate=July 4, 2013}}</ref> Craven and Nathan Scherrer produced the video for the Uprising Creative. Its director of photography was Sing Howe Yam, and Jacquelyn London edited the video for Sunset Edit.<ref name="static">{{cite web|url=http://videostatic.com/watch-it/2013/07/03/justin-timberlake-goes-nsfw-new-video-tunnel-vision|title=Justin Timberlake Goes NSFW with New Video 'Tunnel Vision'|publisher=Video Static|last=Gottlieb|first=Steven|date=July 3, 2013|accessdate=July 4, 2013}}</ref>
The seven-minute video features Timberlake and Timbaland gazing at three nude women; according to Jason Lipshutz of ''Billboard'', the women are wearing flesh-colored [[G-string]]s. In some shots, Timberlake's face is projected onto the women's bodies.<ref name="billboard mv review">{{cite web|url=https://billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/1568870/justin-timberlake-admires-naked-women-in-nsfw-tunnel-vision-video|title=Justin Timberlake Admires Naked Women in NSFW 'Tunnel Vision' Video: Watch|work=Billboard|last=Lipshutz|first=Jason|date=July 3, 2013|accessdate=July 4, 2013}}</ref> Jordan Sargent of ''Spin'' called the set pieces where projections of Timberlake interact with the nude dancers "a fractured dynamic that mirrors 'Tunnel Vision' itself".<ref name="spin">{{cite news|url=http://spin.com/articles/justin-timberlake-tunnel-vision-video/|title=Watch Justin Timberlake Put His Face on Naked Women in 'Tunnel Vision' Video|work=Spin|last=Sargent|first=Jordan|date=July 3, 2013|accessdate=July 5, 2013}}</ref>
Cinya Burton of [[E!]] wrote about Timberlake's video wardrobe, "Apparently when Justin Timberlake isn't in his now-signature suit and tie getup, he's donning [[AllSaints]]." The singer wore two head-to-toe ensembles by the brand. The first was a gray Baxley V-neck T-shirt layered under a white Redono half-sleeved shirt, with casual Charge Chino pants. The second, a darker combination worn while he dances against a lighter background, was a black Resident Crew T-shirt, dark gray Pipe Chino pants, a Duncan denim shirt and black Trap boots. According to Burton, "While his ensembles are both dapper", the nude models in the video attracted more attention.<ref name="wardrobe">{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/437065/gimme-that-justin-timberlake-s-allsaints-looks-in-tunnel-vision-video|title=Gimme That! Justin Timberlake's AllSaints Looks in 'Tunnel Vision' Video|publisher=[[E!]]|last=Burton|first=Cinya|date=July 8, 2013|accessdate=July 12, 2013}}</ref>
=== Critical response and ban === [[File:Robin Thicke 2014.jpg|upright|thumbnail|right|alt=A Caucasian man wearing glasses is smilling|Critics have compared the "Tunnel Vision" video to the one for [[Robin Thicke]]'s "[[Blurred Lines]]".]]
Critics have called the video [[Not suitable for work|NSFW]], comparing it to the 2013 video for "[[Blurred Lines]]" by [[Robin Thicke]] with [[Pharrell Williams]] and [[T.I.]].<ref name="static"/><ref name="billboard mv review"/> In an interview with [[Capital (radio network)|Capital FM]], Thicke responded to a question about the videos' similarity: "No comment. I'll let you do all the talking. It's a subject that has no good ending."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://capitalfm.com/artists/robin-thicke/news/justin-timberlake-tunnel-vision-blurred-lines/|title=Robin Thicke Says "No Comment" On 'Tunnel Vision' And 'Blurred Lines' Comparisons|publisher=[[Capital (radio network)|Capital FM]]|date=July 10, 2013|accessdate=July 12, 2013}}</ref> ''Fact'' magazine called the video's concept simple, and said its production team was unconcerned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://factmag.com/2013/07/03/watch-justin-timberlakes-nsfw-video-for-tunnel-vision/|title=Watch Justin Timberlake's NSFW video for 'Tunnel Vision'|work=Fact|date=July 3, 2013|accessdate=July 6, 2013}}</ref> According to ''Spin''{{'}}s Jordan Sargent, "Like his new album ''The 20/20 Experience'', in which half the songs run longer than seven minutes, the 'Tunnel Vision' video is self-consciously artistic and mature. But the video is also at times effective, particularly when the editing gets choppier during the bridge."<ref name="spin"/>
About the nude women in the video, an [[MTV (UK and Ireland)|MTV UK]] reviewer said that Timberlake drew on Thicke's video.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mtv.co.uk/news/justin-timberlake/385430-justin-timberlake-naked-ladies-new-video-tunnel-vision|title=Justin Timberlake Recruits Nude Women For NSFW Video|publisher=[[MTV (UK and Ireland)|MTV UK]]|date=July 4, 2013|accessdate=July 6, 2013}}</ref> ''The Huffington Post''{{'}}s Sarah Dean wrote that Timberlake used a tip from Thicke to accompany a "great" song with a video objectifying women who enjoy dancing nude, criticizing the use of three women for a song with lyrics about a single love interest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/07/04/justin-timberlake-tunnel-vision-video-naked-women_n_3545159.html|title=Justin Timberlake Banned 'Tunnel Vision' Video Features Multiple Naked Women (NSFW Video)|publisher=The Huffington Post|last=Dean|first=Sarah|date=July 4, 2013|accessdate=July 6, 2013}}</ref> According to Tamar Anitai of MTV Buzzworthy, Timberlake wanted to live his life and celebrate his album's success: "Oh, come on! Don't complain. You bitched and moaned endlessly when Justin Timberlake stopped making music for six years, so don't get all Veruca Salty when he comes back with boobs to spare and boobs to share."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2013/07/03/justin-timberlakes-topless-tunnel-vision-video-gif-reactions/|title=Justin Timberlake's Topless 'Tunnel Vision' Video: GIF Reactions|publisher=MTV Buzzworthy|last=Anitai|first=Tamar|date=July 3, 2013|accessdate=July 6, 2013}}</ref>
In her review, Rachel Maresca of the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' wrote that Timberlake slurred some of the song's explicit lyrics in the video.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/justin-timberlake-releases-nude-music-video-tunnel-vision-article-1.1390188|title=Justin Timberlake's nude 'Tunnel Vision' music video banned from YouTube, causes fireworks on July 4|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|last=Maresca|first=Rachel|date=July 4, 2013|accessdate=July 6, 2013}}</ref> According to Kathy McCabe of [[News Corp Australia]], Timberlake escalated the pop-porn movement with the video: "With mummy blogger outrage over Robin Thicke's exploitation of topless women for his Blurred Lines video – and its questionable lyrics – still raging, Timberlake has gone even further in his clip".<ref name="aus review">{{cite web|url=http://news.com.au/entertainment/music/justin-timberlake8217s-new-video-for-single-tunnel-vision-his-raunchiest-yet-and-robin-thicke8217s-new-song-give-it-2-u-more-explicit-than-blurred-lines/story-e6frfn09-1226674421602|title=Justin Timberlake's new video for single Tunnel Vision his raunchiest yet, and Robin Thicke's new song Give It 2 U more explicit than Blurred Lines|publisher=[[News Corp Australia]]|last=McCabe|first=Kathy|date=July 4, 2013|accessdate=July 6, 2013}}</ref> McCabe wrote that male pop singers have been influenced by [[Rihanna]] and [[Katy Perry]], who have "stripped down in the name of a hit. Or art. Or freedom of expression, depending on the press release spin".<ref name="aus review"/> ''[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]]''{{'}}s Robin Murray wrote that pop music has lacked raunchiness and sex appeal for some time, and Timberlake's return was needed: "Lavish, lush and 21st century in a direct, shocking fashion, the video finds Justin Timberlake on perfect preening form."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://clashmusic.com/videos/justin-timberlake-tunnel-vision-explicit|title=Justin Timberlake – Tunnel Vision (Explicit)|work=[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]]|last=Murray|first=Rbon|date=July 4, 2013|accessdate=July 6, 2013}}</ref>
After the video's release it was banned from YouTube with a message saying, "This video has been removed as a violation of YouTube's policy on nudity or sexual content".<ref name="video ban"/> The website quickly restored the video with a content warning and the requirement that viewers sign in (to verify their age). Although a YouTube representative declined to comment on individual videos, he issued a statement: "While our guidelines generally prohibit nudity, we make exceptions when it is presented in an educational, documentary or artistic context, and take care to add appropriate warnings and age restrictions".<ref name="video ban">{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/436612/justin-timberlake-debuts-racy-tunnel-vision-music-video-amid-brief-youtube-ban|title=Justin Timberlake Debuts Racy "Tunnel Vision" Music Video Amid Brief YouTube Ban|publisher=E!|last=Grossberg|first=Josh|date=July 5, 2013|accessdate=July 5, 2013}}</ref>
== Live performances == Timberlake first performed "Tunnel Vision" at the [[Phoenix Park]] concert in [[Dublin, Ireland]], as part of a set list which included "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]", "[[SexyBack]]" and "[[My Love (Justin Timberlake song)|My Love]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rte.ie/ten/news/2013/0711/461819-40-000-bring-sexy-back-with-justin-timberlake/|title=40,000 bring 'Sexy Back' with Justin Timberlake|publisher=[[RTÉ.ie]]|date=July 11, 2013|accessdate=July 12, 2013}}</ref> In a review of the concert, John Balfe of [[entertainment.ie]] wrote: "Even the album's more well-known songs like 'Tunnel Vision', 'Mirrors' and 'Suit & Tie' don't yet have the same weight in the setlist as some of JT's more established hits and it was songs like 'SexyBack' that really got the 40,000 strong crowd to move".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.ie/music/news/Live-Review-Justin-Timberlake-Phoenix-Park-10th-July/200606.htm|title=Live Review: Justin Timberlake, Phoenix Park – 10th July|publisher=[[entertainment.ie]]|last=Balfe|first=John|date=July 11, 2013|accessdate=July 12, 2013}}</ref> On July 12 Timberlake appeared on the main stage at the [[Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park]] in [[Stratford, London]] as part of the [[Wireless Festival]], performing "Tunnel Vision" and other songs dressed in black and wearing a black [[fedora]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nme.com/news/justin-timberlake/71419|title=Jay-Z joins Justin Timberlake onstage at London's Wireless Festival|work=[[NME]]|date=July 13, 2013|accessdate=July 13, 2013}}</ref> The song was on the [[set list]]s of Timberlake's 2013 [[Legends of the Summer Stadium Tour]] with rapper [[Jay-Z]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hollywoodreporter.com/review/justin-timberlake-jay-z-affirm-594902|title=Justin Timberlake, Jay Z Affirm Their 'Legends' Status with Rose Bowl Bow: Concert Review|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|last=Godley|first=Chris|date=July 29, 2013|accessdate=May 25, 2014}}</ref> and his fifth worldwide tour, the 2013–15 [[The 20/20 Experience World Tour|20/20 Experience World Tour]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wpgc.cbslocal.com/2014/02/24/justin-timberlake-2020-experience-world-tour-set-list/|title=Justin Timberlake's '20/20 Experience' World Tour Set List|publisher=[[CBS Local Media]]|date=February 24, 2014|accessdate=May 21, 2014}}</ref>
== Track listing == #"Tunnel Vision" (radio edit) — 4:45 #"Tunnel Vision" — 6:46
== Credits and personnel == Adapted from ''The 20/20 Experience'' album liner notes.<ref name="Album Credits">{{cite AV media notes |title=[[The 20/20 Experience]] |others=[[Justin Timberlake]] |year=2013 |type=booklet |publisher=[[RCA Records]], a division of [[Sony Music Entertainment]] |location=[[New York City]], NY}}</ref>
{{col-begin}} {{col-2}} '''Recording location''' *Vocals recorded and mixed at Larrabee Studios, [[North Hollywood, Los Angeles|North Hollywood]], California
'''Personnel''' *Timothy "Timbaland" Mosley – Producer, songwriter *Justin Timberlake – Mixer, producer, songwriter, vocal producer, vocal arranger *Jerome "J-Roc" Harmon – Keyboards, producer, songwriter *James Fauntleroy – Songwriter *Chris Godbey – Engineer, mixer *Jimmy Douglass – Mixer *Alejandro Baima – Assistant engineer *Elliot Ives – Guitar {{col-2}}
'''Video credits'''<ref name="static"/> *Jonathan Craven – Director, producer *Simon McLoughlin – Director *Jeff Nicholas – Director *Nathan Scherrer – Producer *The Uprising Creative – Production company *Sing Howe Yam – Director of photography *Jacquelyn London – Editor *Sunset Edit – Editing company {{col-end}}
